beeswax.name: Beeswax (yellow)
beeswax.description: Natural wax from Apis mellifera. Increases bar hardness. Melt into oils before adding lye. Melting point 62-64°C.

sourcing.productionMethod: Secreted by honey bees (Apis mellifera), harvested from hive cappings and comb during honey extraction.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: China is the largest producer. Quality varies significantly by region and processing method.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Bee welfare is a growing concern in commercial beekeeping. Organic certification indicates no synthetic pesticide exposure. Some vegans avoid beeswax as an animal product.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Beeswax and Carnauba Wax

candelilla-wax.name: Candelilla wax
candelilla-wax.description: Plant-based wax from Euphorbiaceae species. Vegan alternative to beeswax. Melting point 68.5-72.5°C.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted from Euphorbia antisyphilitica shrub stems by boiling in acidified water.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Mexico produces ~95% of global supply. Wild-harvested from Chihuahuan Desert region.

environmental: Wild harvesting pressure on native plant populations
political: Mexican government regulates harvest to prevent overexploitation
ethicalConcerns.notes: Candelilla harvest supports rural communities in northern Mexico. Sustainable harvesting practices are important to prevent overexploitation of wild populations.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Cosmetic Waxes (Beeswax, Carnauba, Candelilla)

carnauba-wax.name: Carnauba wax
carnauba-wax.description: Hardest natural wax from Copernicia cerifera palm. Vegan. Brittle alone, combine with softer waxes. Melting point 82-85°C.

sourcing.productionMethod: Scraped from dried leaves of Copernicia prunifera palm, then refined and bleached.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Brazil produces virtually 100% of global supply, primarily from northeastern states (Piauí, Ceará).

social: Seasonal work with low wages for harvesters
ethicalConcerns.notes: Carnauba palm is not cultivated; wax is harvested from wild or semi-wild trees. Provides income for rural communities but working conditions vary. Fair trade certified sources available.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Beeswax and Carnauba Wax

grapefruit-seed-extract.name: Grapefruit seed extract (GSE)
grapefruit-seed-extract.description: Extract from Citrus paradisi seeds. Antioxidant, extends shelf life. Not a broad-spectrum preservative. Verify purity.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted from Citrus paradisi seeds and pulp using glycerin or other solvents.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Byproduct of grapefruit juice industry. United States (Florida) and China are major producers.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Byproduct of citrus juice industry with minimal additional environmental impact. Some commercial GSE products have been found adulterated with synthetic preservatives; verify purity from reputable suppliers.

references.section: Antimicrobial Efficacy of Grapefruit Seed Extract

honey.name: Honey
honey.description: Natural humectant from Apis mellifera. Increases lather, adds natural sugars. Heats soap significantly - freeze after moulding.

sourcing.productionMethod: Collected from honey bee hives, filtered and sometimes pasteurized.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: China is the world's largest producer. Adulteration with corn syrup is a known issue in global supply chains.

environmental: Colony collapse disorder threatens bee populations
ethicalConcerns.notes: Honey adulteration is widespread; True Source certification verifies origin. Colony collapse disorder is a serious environmental concern. Some vegans avoid honey as an animal product.

rosemary-oleoresin.name: Rosemary oleoresin extract (ROE)
rosemary-oleoresin.description: Oil-soluble extract from Rosmarinus officinalis leaves. Retards rancidity. Rich in carnosic acid (7%+). Add to oils before mixing.

sourcing.productionMethod: Supercritical CO2 extraction or solvent extraction from Rosmarinus officinalis leaves.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Mediterranean region is the traditional production center. Spain is a major producer.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Rosemary is a widely cultivated herb with established sustainable farming practices. Low environmental and social concerns.

references.section: Rosemary (Rosmarinus officinalis L.) extract: antiproliferative and antioxidant properties

silk-amino-acids.name: Silk amino acids (hydrolyzed silk)
silk-amino-acids.description: Hydrolyzed silk protein peptides (MW ~300-1000 Da). Enhances lather creaminess. Rich in glycine, alanine, serine. Add to cooled lye water.

sourcing.productionMethod: Hydrolyzed from Bombyx mori (mulberry silkworm) cocoons using enzymes or acids.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: China produces ~80% of world silk supply. Silkworms are typically killed during cocoon harvesting.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Conventional silk production kills silkworms during cocoon processing. 'Peace silk' or 'Ahimsa silk' allows moths to emerge before harvesting, though this is rare for cosmetic-grade silk amino acids.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Silk Protein Ingredients

sodium-lactate.name: Sodium lactate
sodium-lactate.description: Sodium salt of lactic acid (C3H5NaO3). Add to cooled lye water before combining with oils. Reduces unmoulding time.

sourcing.productionMethod: Produced by neutralizing lactic acid (from corn or sugar fermentation) with sodium hydroxide.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Usually derived from fermented plant sugars (corn, beet, cane). Major industrial chemical with global supply chains.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Typically derived from plant fermentation. Non-GMO certification available for those avoiding GMO corn-derived products.

sugar.name: Sugar (sucrose)
sugar.description: Sucrose (C12H22O11). Dissolve in water portion before adding lye. Increases lather volume.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted and refined from sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum) or sugar beet (Beta vulgaris).
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Brazil is the world's largest producer and exporter. Cane sugar dominates tropical regions; beet sugar is common in temperate climates.

environmental: Sugarcane cultivation linked to habitat loss
social: Historical and ongoing labour rights concerns in sugarcane industry
Fair wage issues for cane cutters
ethicalConcerns.notes: Sugar industry has significant labour and environmental concerns, particularly in sugarcane production. Fair Trade and Bonsucro certifications address labour conditions and environmental practices.

table-salt.name: Salt (sodium chloride)
table-salt.description: Sodium chloride (NaCl). Dissolve in water portion before adding lye. Increases hardness. Above 3% may inhibit lather.

sourcing.productionMethod: Mined from underground deposits (rock salt) or evaporated from seawater/brine.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Major industrial commodity with global supply chains. China and United States are largest producers.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Widely available commodity with minimal ethical concerns. Mined salt avoids microplastic contamination found in some sea salt.

tussah-silk.name: Tussah silk fibers
tussah-silk.description: Natural silk fibers from wild Antheraea moths. Dissolves in hot lye water (170-190°F). Increases lather creaminess.

sourcing.productionMethod: Harvested from wild Antheraea (tussah/tasar) moth cocoons after moth emergence, or from broken cocoons.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Wild silk from forest-fed moths. India is the largest tussah silk producer. Often collected after moth emergence.

ethicalConcerns.notes: Tussah silk is often considered more ethical than mulberry silk because cocoons are frequently collected after moth emergence (peace silk). However, practices vary by source. Supports forest-dependent communities in India.

references.section: Safety Assessment of Silk Protein Ingredients as Used in Cosmetics

vitamin-e-tocopherol.name: Vitamin E (mixed tocopherols)
vitamin-e-tocopherol.description: Mixed tocopherols (alpha, beta, gamma, delta). Antioxidant to prevent oil oxidation. Add to oils before mixing.

sourcing.productionMethod: Extracted from vegetable oils (soybean, sunflower, wheat germ) or synthesized chemically.
sourcing.supplyChainNotes: Natural vitamin E typically extracted from soybean oil deodorizer distillate. Synthetic forms are common.

environmental: If soy-derived, may be linked to soy cultivation concerns
ethicalConcerns.notes: Natural vitamin E is often derived from soybean oil processing. Non-GMO and sunflower-derived options available for those avoiding GMO soy. Synthetic vitamin E (dl-alpha-tocopherol) is petroleum-derived.
